People are super friendly too; my boyfriend has met some guys who are cool and swap tips and they belay each other when I'm not there with him to do it. Really, really cool environment. They offer fitness classes, which is obviously awesome, and you can use the pool as well (which technically belongs to the swim place next door). So much variety! Everyone on the staff is totally friendly and down to earth. The feeling you get from rock climbing is incomparable; you feel so accomplished and strong after you climb a wall you didn't think you could reach the top of, it's wonderful. And the soreness afterwards! You really know you worked your body well. Last but not least: there's lotion in the ladies bathroom. I know it sounds silly, but I'm a hand lotion addict. Especially after all that climbing and chalk and bouldering...it's so nice to get a nice pump of hand lotion complimentary :) considering this economy, places that offer such extras are A+ in my book! It's the little things in life ; )

I recently moved and I miss DRG so much! This place is amazing. Well worth the membership pricing (you get unlimited climbing, unlimited group fitness classes, and unlimited Crossfit classes - can't beat that). It's kid and family friendly, you rarely have to wait for equipment in the weight area (because most people are climbing) and the staff is super friendly and helpful. New routes go up all the time so you'll never get bored and, of all the touchstone gyms, DRG has the best overall layout and variety of routes and pitches.

My first experience at Diablo Rock was with a bunch of 10 year old kids.  My daughter's good friend had a birthday party there.  I was amazed at the courage of all those whippersnappers scooting up the wall.  More amazing was the incredibly courteous, helpful and friendly staff.  They were very attentive to keeping the kids engaged and most importantly; safe.My daughter and I loved it so much, we (and her sister) went back a couple of weeks later.  I took a belay class (that's the person holding the "security rope"), while my kids had an hour long kids climbing session.  I am now certified to belay for my kids - we can show up, drop $10 bucks each and they can scurry up and down the walls like spiderman - all they want.  It is an awesome way to spend a day with the kids, and a great way to peel their butts off the computer or TV.It is also great for adults.  What a great way to spend some time getting fit, having fun and being able to talk to friends while you are climbing.  It is really cool that the vibe in Diablo Rock can support a bunch of kids, 20 yr olds, and an 40 year old fart like me scaling the same wall, and everyone is having a blast - there is no generational tension in the gym at all.  I can't imagine that happening at any other gym around here.Try it - you'll love it!!!!Rob

If you have never belayed before  and want a solid place to learn it, this is it!The staff here will ensure that they go over all the basics with you and stay with you until they feel you are solid in all basic safety.Go here and learn the right way, the only way!

Yesterday was fun!Free admission. check.Free food. double check.There were also good routes and it wasn't super crowded, which is why I have been staying away from Mission Cliffs. It's a little intimidating as a newbie. So I did this one 5.8...It was hard, but Doug had me hanging up there like a marionette until I finished it. I'm glad he did.

Sunday Afternoon with the kids and I don't want them watching TV or playing video games...So Rock Climbing it is...They have a great deal, at least on Sundays, between 11-3 where the kids get to climb a different type of wall with instructor for an hour, all for $15 bucks! The instructors are great and the kids really dug it...You might need to have the kids wait a bit as kids will rotate out after there hour and it is drop in.Decent staff and a great hobby for the family.

Touchstone is by far my favourite climbing gym, probably because when I got started climbing there just over 3 years ago, I got to know everyone in the place really well.It's more family oriented than Berkeley's Ironworks and Mission Cliffs in the city, and I do enjoy having those climber kids around.  I don't know, it's just less pretentious or something.  I guess I like kids!My favourite part of the gym?  The SLACKLINE.  Oh, man, it's kind of unCANNY how much I miss it.  There's a certain balance 'knack' you have to get when you first start out on it, and one day I just spent hours on it, perfecting my 'knack,' attempting to walk forward and backward all the way across.  Gah, I love it.  I wish I could afford a gym membership again...and the CLIMBING!  I LOVE CLIMBING!  Except, it's been over a year since the last time I climbed.  I moved the city and started taking more classes (plus working), thus, I cannot afford a membership anymore.  But when I was really into it, in the days of Touchstone Concord, I went to the gym religiously.  Before work.  After work.  After hours?  I could not be stopped. The walls are high, and some of the routes are challenging, I think I got up to the the high 5.11's.  Maybe 5.11abc or d.  I can't remember.  Maybe even some 5.12's on a good day.  Plus, after getting to know everyone, I felt like I had my own coaches, everyone supported everyone else, always cheering me on.Not to mention the classes.  I used to take an ABs class a few times a week.  And even yoga sometimes!   Plus, there's all kinds of regular gym equipment and weights and stuff.Oh, I miss Touchstone and I miss climbing.  *sigh*  I still have all my gear, so if you need a climbing partner and you have a buddy pass... hit me up!!

Joined this gym in February... and I LOVE it! I don't climb, yet. I took their intro and basic classes, had a lot of fun with it and hope to explore climbing more soon. However, I do know that they change up the climbing routes frequently, because I have seen them doing so on several occasions.I joined this gym because it does not have the 'meat market' mentality of other gyms in the area. I was impressed by the distinct lack of 'gym bunnies' and 'muscle heads' who seem to do little more than take up space and waste everybody's time. It has a great selection of cardio equipment, exercise machines and free weights. The yoga classes are fantastic! I also try to take advantage of the steam room every chance I get. Definitely worth the money, and what was the final selling point was the fact that they don't lock you in to a 'contract' like so many other places do.

In spite of its relationship to Berkeley Ironworks, I find this gym fun.  The primary difference is in the staff (who are much nicer) and the fact that more of the patrons seem to climb.  I also like their routes -- the walls are varied in angle and features, and the routes sometimes take you up pillars and across rooves and then up again to the ceiling; or along slabby sections to a round arete and up.  The lead routes are way overhung, though.  I took one look and opted out of the lead test.

This place is huge compared to Berkeley Ironworks and Great Western Power Company. There are lots and lots of routes to choose from. I definetly recommend this place if you live nearby.Unfortunately for me, this gym is out in Concord. I went once for a party, but can't see myself trekking out to Concord on BART to go here normally. It's probably a good thing. I've heard this gym gets overrun with children on the weekends since it is in the suburbs.

I am a fan of the yoga program here, and appreciate that the gym isn't a warehouse full of machines machines machines and obnoxious gym rats/bunnies. I often see kids with their families trying out the equipment, and there are always people with smiles on their faces so you know they're having a good time. The locker room is clean and quiet, soap and such provided in the showers so you don't have to carry messy bottles with you. Nice!I haven't climbed a wall yet (I've only been for the yoga so far and still working on healing a shoulder injury), but I'm looking forward to it!

Best gym in the area, hands down. A bit pricey, but if you take advantage of all that they have to offer, (and I am amazed on how much has been added in the last year) you will feel like its $ well spent. The staff is super friendly, very helpful, and not as judgemental as other climbing gyms I have been to. The people that go there are super-cool, and you will have no d-baggy Affliction-roided out types here. Come during a comp and enjoy good music, beer, pizza, and strangers cheering each other on in every level. Sit under the "Prow" and be amazed by kids and adults making climbing look easy. The ONLY gym I would support in the area!

I consider myself lucky to have stumbled upon Diablo Rock Gym and to have such an amazing climbing facility relatively nearby. I have visited DRG a handful of times now and have not had a single bad experience. Each visit turns out to be a great workout and overall fun experience. After every visit I feel physically challenged, mentally sharp and have an overall sense of fulfillment. I'll be bringing friends and family members here to share my newfound passion and excitement for climbing with them in a good environment. Sidenote: Bouldering is WAY harder then it looks!

Yes, yet another awesome Touchstone gym.  Great staff.  Perfect bouldering area with lots of problems.  Love how the bouldering surface is distinct from the other Touchstone gyms.  Great top rope routes - lots of slabs/balance routes and overhangs.  BIW and GWPC are my home base.  I'll definitely visit DRG when I can.  Can't wait to check out the new crack.  Also love the cardio area for interval training.  Yay climbing and Touchstone!

I am in the area for a while visiting family and decided to hit up a local rock gym, this one was the closest to my family home. I will definitely be driving a little further to visit a better gym next time, as my experience here was like none other I've had at any rock gym. The woman with the accent working the front desk was horribly rude. She told us we needed to pass a belay test to climb so we had to wait about 15 minutes as she tested someone else then went back to sitting at the front desk and didn't even acknowledge us at the testing ropes. No "be right with you" or anything. So she finally comes to test us and was Shockley rude and condescending and was treating us as if we are completely dumb. Which is funny because we are definitely seasoned climbers so it's pretty frustrating to have to test for this anyways. So after "testing" (talking down to us) one of us on belay she mumbles something, leaves and goes back to talking on the phone. We stood for another five minutes before I was just ready to hop on a rope and forget about this stupid test when finally another one of the staff just gave us our test passed cards and agreed that his coworker was "kind of dumb" so definitely warning all my climb friends in the Bay Area to not waste their time or money with this one.

My new favorite past time is climbing a wall... I was so inspired by my experience that I purchased gear and a membership to Diablo Rock Gym after my very first climbing experience two weeks ago!  I am also embarrased enough to say that I even blogged about the experience.  But enough about me...There are really great routes to choose from here, and plenty of different levels for the novice and professional climbers to choose from.  The staff is very friendly, and tried to give me the best discount they could for being a student, etc.  You get a $50 discount off the Initiation Fee if you have a valid Student ID.  The monthly membership is great because there is no contract, and no additional fees.All yoga, spin, and other classes are included in membership.  The locker rooms are super clean, and they even had a hair dryer for use.  There are also plenty of day lockers for storing your stuff.  If you are just thinking about a membership, or don't want the commitment - it's only $10 to climb before 3:00pm, or $16 after.  The classes are only $12 if you are not a member.  It's nice to know that you can still get a yoga class for under $15 somewhere in the East Bay!

my home away from home ...this place has a monster good vibe.  It is so...not the "gym rat" energy.  The ages range from 14ish to 64ish (trust me I know) and all levels of rock climbing are appreciated and encouraged.  There is nice bouldering area but, for that, i recommend mission cliffs!  Andrew, Dustin, Eric, Paul...the main guys at the counter are fabulously helpful...not to mention easy on the eyes!  bummer fact: it closes early 10pm ...not good for all you 24 hour folks.

My son and niece now outgrew the rock climbing wall in the park so we went to try Diablo Rock Gym a month ago.  I was going to see if this is a place for our son's birthday party next year.We walked to the front desk and saw an employee behind the counter who didn't seem to care for our business.  After we filled out the release forms, we returned to the front desk and the same guy led us to another employee who just looked at us, didn't say a word and looked up to another child who was half way on the wall.  At this point,  I didn't want to be rude but had no choice and asked what we were supposed to do next.  The employee then told us there were three kids who he was assigned to.  After 10 mins, it was our turn.  My son and niece enjoyed the climb but this employee kept chatting with his co-worker and didn't hear the children when they wanted to come down.  This whole experience with Diablo Rock Gym was disastrous.

Great Staff ! Very clean facilities and stafff are cleaning and polishing daily, no odors. Pool is very clean without that strong chlorine odor.  Lots of classes including Zumba, Yoga, Water Aerobics, Water Splash, Cycling. Great Rock Climbing training and practice.. Excellent Personal Trainers  and Swim Instructors.  Highly RecommendTo the Owners :  PLEASE Offer a Daytime Water Aerobics class , lots of us from SSM want a class  so much that my friends in Concord and Walnut Creek and Pleasant Hill drive all the way to Livermore three times a week for a daytime water aerobics class at another gym, you will definitely fill the classes :-))

Came here a couple months ago to hang out with some friends who are recreational rock climbers.  I had to the chance to check out what they all keep talking about.  Although rocking climbing isn't something  im into, this gym features a huge work out area with a bunch of cardio machines, spin classes and big ass rocks to climb on.  Staff was friendly and the changing rooms were clean.

Rates are comparable to Planet Granite (referring to the one in San Francisco), but I'd probably say the most notable difference was the fact that Diablo Rock Gym uses the older model of harnesses and ATC devices instead of the Grigri, so the belay test is slightly different.  Aside from that, the ropes seemed a bit stiff and worn on the ends but the staff were nice (when you're finally able to flag one down).

I come to concord the most out of all the gyms but it is still the nearest and dearest to my heart. generally good slab routes ftw! the staff is all really nice and am now buddybuddy with a few. and the absolute best thing about this plcace? THE MUTHAFIN STEAM ROOM! oh man, my love of steam rooms is ridiculous. there is also one of the trainers there, Rubin, who is very nice and open to talk to whenever he is there.

Fantastic! This gym has more classes than any other gym I've been to: cycling, TRX, Crossfit, yoga, core, and others. In addition to being a great general gym, it also stands out as a wonderful climbing gym. The route setters do a great job putting up routes/problems for people of all levels. Also, there is access to an indoor pool. The front desk staff are friendly and helpful. The overall feel is laid-back. I don't feel judged here. I have nothing but positive things to say about this gym.

Diablo Rock Gym is the place I call home for my fitness needs, so deep down I love it - but this is an unbiased view from a relatively new climber - I've been a member of Touchstone for 3 months now. First off 90% of the time this place is pretty peaceful. There are a lot of route options for belay, lead and bouldering, with ranges in difficulty that will suit any level climber (5.2 is the lowest I've seen). The walls are shorter than the other Touchstone locations, but personally I like that because I'm still building muscle. The staff is great about regularly cycling the routes to keep things new and exciting. Great overhang on both the lead wall and the bouldering wall, even though I'm still too novice to touch them. Overall it's a fantastic gym - very open and inviting. I've never had a problem getting a weight/cardio machine even at peak hours of the day. Never have to wait for belay routes. Never have to wait for boulder routes. They offer classes every day (Yoga, Cycle, & Zumba) though I haven't checked any of them out yet (not big on classes). It's just a great place to get in, do your thing, shower, and go home. The staff are all very friendly and helpful. Bonus for me that it's 5 minutes from my house.Now the cons, because every place has them... Luckily there are only two, both of which I consider tolerable. The biggest "meh" I have with DRG is that it seems like they run a babysitting service from at least 4:45pm (when I usually arrive) until about 7-ish. During the week there's quite often a group of kids running around with one or two young guys monitoring them - MOST of the time. I've honestly had kids from that group climb up bouldering routes that criss-cross with mine first being below me and then above me (they're so quick!) to the  point where I have to pause my course because I don't want to have one of them fall/jump on me or vice versa. They often socialize at the bottom of belay climbs just swinging on the ropes (not climbing), or tear around the gym at high speeds. I understand it's the suburbs, but I'm there to work out, not to dodge children. There should be a level of maturity in these kids, otherwise they shouldn't be in a gym in the first place.The only other issue I've had is that the showers don't seem to get very hot. I don't need scalding, but something that is above lukewarm would be nice. I've been in the shower with it on as hot as it will go and still had goosebumps, and that's no good when all I want to do is wash the sweat out of my hair - I should have enough heat for a 7 minute shower that won't leave me shivering.Other than those two small issues, Concord is great, and even if these situations remain the same I will continue to go there because the pros of diverse and mostly available climbs/machines, relative tranquility, and proximity to my house definitely outweigh the random unruly children and less than hot showers.

I've been a member here for over a year now, and I love it. Friendly staff, good yoga classes and very social crowd, for the most part. I've been able to pick up random climbing buddies after hanging out in the bouldering pit a while, but on days when I don't want to talk to anyone and just want to climb, I can do that too. Towel service, steam room, sauna, pro shop (SNACKS!! need more calories to burn!), and plenty of folks around to help give tips and suggestions make this a good place to learn to climb. Seems like there's always a group of Boy Scouts, a birthday party, or multi-generational family group there in the afternoons and evenings, but the mornings are pretty quiet and calm if you prefer that. As of March 2011 they just got in new rental shoes, which is nice. Better to get your own if you want to stick to the walls on a regular basis, though. Oh yeah... REI is practically across the street (Willow Pass Road), so you can do that pretty easily. Check out their rope and bouldering competitions throughout the year, and get a membership so you can check out all the other Touchstone gyms. Totally worth it. I started out as a rookie last year, and between all the climbing and yoga I've done there, I feel fantastic.
A couple of my friends and I decided to try this place out.  Fortunately, we found this spot.  Would definetly go again.

3 and 1/2 really.  But only because I go for the yoga. World Yoga in WC closed suddenly and left the yoga community orphaned.  Sarah P. from Diablo Rock invited me to try 2 free classes.  Since I'd only practiced @ WY, I'd say my bar is probably set a little high for my yoga experience.  The class was great but I was distracted by the music from the spin class in the next room.  I am not used to conversations outside the door.  But the class was challenging and free.  For future yoga classes, it $10 to drop in.  A bargain considering the usual $15/$16 rate.  Maybe I'll get used to the noise?

Great place to get a great workout. It is a gym, but unlike any other. The fact that you can come in, get your rock climbing shoes if you don't have any, and either boulder or rock climb  all you want is something that is great about this gym. You can work on the machines (elliptical, treadmill, etc.) of course, but just the environment is nice. Small, isolated gym, but worth traveling to. I'm not a fan of gyms because of the many kinds of people that go there who are very vain. Here? You don't get that vibe. Everybody is doing their thing and not worried about what you do which is nice when you sometimes want to try something new without you having that feeling that others may be judging you.

Let me be clear about what I'm writing about: the claim that they have a POOL... that you can swim in.  I wanted to give them a try because they offered a pool.... well if you can call it a pool.  No doubt the rock climbing part of the gym looks fantastic, but if you want to swim - you are better off in your bathtub.  The locker rooms that have the steam / sauna / showers and lockers are NOT attached to the "pool".  In order to get to the locker rooms where you can change before going to the "pool" you have to walk through the entirety of the gym - around the weights section, through some doors, around the "pool" - then into a hallway that has a men's restroom sign.  At first I couldn't believe that this was the locker room for the pool.  Upon entering it turns out I was half right.  It was the place where the gym owners expect you to change and shower if you are using the pool, but it was NO locker room.  The List:  the lights half work and then turn off on you after 5 minutes (only way to get them to turn back on it to go back to the door and wave your hand at the sensor), even with the lights on the toilet had NO light, the VAST majority of the lockers are broken with no way to actually lock them, the few lockers that work are on the bottom and in the corner, the "shower" is a hole in the wall with no curtain (looked as though it had one of those shower heads that spray ice cold water at you with speeds that could pierce skin or that it would just trickle out), the whole hole smelt like mold and a homeless persons dirty socks. Now lets move onto the main event... the "pool".  If you are a swimmer and by swimmer I mean someone who swims... not someone who swims a lap or two and then lallygags for one end to the other - this "pool" is NOT for You!  It is perhaps the dingiest thing I have seen in a great while.  The entire "pool" is 3 ft-ish deep.  I'm 6'2" and when I swim I don't like my fingers hitting the bottom, and although I am flexible and can get pretty compact during a flip turn, the water level is such that it is not sufficient enough for me to do one. To sum up the whole experience including the entire look of the "pool" SAD SAD & SAD!! Probably the WORST pool I've swam in since moving to CA. I'm sorry I wasted the money on the month of unlimited swimming.

great crowd, great staff, great routes, and now a pool being put it too?? screw 24 hour fitness, this place is worth every penny, now if they only rented lofts next door so i didnt have to drive there every day my life would be perfect.

this is my local gym.  i usually boulder.  they have a full fitness center and decent locker rooms.  the staff is friendly and down to earth.  and the other members there are cool too.  i always end up talking to people while i climb.  to help them with a problem or be helped.  i became a member back in june of 07 and i have learned a lot from this place considering how small their bouldering area is.  its not as large as ironworks in berkeley but it gets the job done and it doesnt get as busy as them.  and the physical trainer there is a former nfl player named ruben.  everything you need to do to train is here except for a pool and track but whatever.  i love this place.  not only do you get a membership to other good gyms, you also get a free subscription to Rock and Ice, a magazine that goes for $5.99 an issue.

totally rockin'!  smaller than berkeley ironworks and sf mission cliffs, but plenty of quality routes (same route setters) and far fewer people.  and it costs less to be a member here.  nice lead routes on the prow, which is fantastically overhung.  i dig it.

Awesome place. The place is really clean and organized. I went their with my youth group and everyone loved it. The people are nice and the price isn't bad. You get the most bang for the buck and I can guarantee and awesome time. The place is filled with options and it's an adventure.
